citation.article-title: A new species of oral Streptococcus isolated from Sprague-Dawley rats, Streptococcus orisratti sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Streptococcus orisratti sp. nov.
Streptococcus orisratti (o.ris.rat'ti. L. gen. n. oris of the mouth; L. gen. masc. n. ratti of the rat ; M.L. gen. n. orisratti of the mouth of the rat)
Cells are facultatively anaerobic, non-motile, catalase-negative, Gram-positive cocci that occur in pairs or short chains.
Colonies are white, circular or irregular, 0.5-1.0 mm in diameter and α-haemolytic on sheepblood agar.
Growth occurs at 45 °C, in 40% bile and at pH 9.6, but not in the presence of 6.5% NaCl or at 50 °C.

Ferments galactose, glucose, fructose, mannose, glucosamine, amygdalin, arbutin, salicin, cellobiose, maltose, lactose, melibiose, sucrose, trehalose, inulin, raffinose, starch and glycogen, but not arabinose, mannitol, sorbitol or melezitose.
The final pH in glucose-containing culture is 4±3±4±4.
Aesculin and starch are hydrolysed but arginine is not.
GTF and FTF are not produced. S. orisratti belongs to Lancefield group A.
The G­+C content of DNA is 39.6-43.5 mol%.
Source: the tooth surface of laboratory rats.
